word.entryDescription: a light material made from chemicals
word.entryExample: I don't like these shoes. They're plastic.

word.entryDescription: a flat round object you put food on
word.entryExample: Watch out – the plate's hot.

word.entryDescription: 1. to take part in a sport or game 2. to perform music on an instrument or instruments 3. to play games or have fun
word.entryExample: 1. I love playing sport. 2. My brother plays the drums in a band. 3. Can I play with my friends in the park today?

word.entryDescription: a story performed by actors, especially in a theatre
word.entryExample: I love drama, whether it's a play or a dramatic film.

word.entryDescription: to play a team sport in which people try to kick a ball into a goal
word.entryExample: I play football every day.

word.entryDescription: to be problematic
word.entryExample: Our printer is playing up and my computer crashed last night.

word.entryDescription: somebody who takes part in a sport or game
word.entryExample: William ran past two players and scored a goal.

word.entryDescription: an outside area at a school where the children can play
word.entryExample: The children are playing football in the playground.

word.entryDescription: taking part or competing in a game of cards
word.entryExample: We were sitting in the park, playing cards.

word.entryDescription: a list of recordings to be played; used for organizing a personal digital music collection
word.entryExample: I have a lot of playlists that I have put together for when I go for a run.

word.entryDescription: somebody who writes plays
word.entryExample: William Shakespeare was a famous playwright.

word.entryDescription: something you say to make a request more polite
word.entryExample: Can you repeat that, please?

word.entryDescription: the feeling of happiness, enjoyment, or satisfaction
word.entryExample: Some people learn foreign languages just for pleasure.

word.entryDescription: a large quantity of something which is enough or more than enough
word.entryExample: Nowadays, there is plenty of choice for consumers.

word.entryDescription: the main story of a film, book, etc
word.entryExample: The way the plot developed was superb – I've never seen a better film.

word.entryDescription: to connect an electrical device to the main supply of electricity or to another electrical device
word.entryExample: Then you plug in the phone and charger to the socket.

word.entryDescription: catching or shooting animals illegally, without permission
word.entryExample: At least 10,000 species of animals are disappearing every year. The main causes are deforestation and poaching.

word.entryDescription: a small bag fixed to an item of clothing in which you can put things
word.entryExample: When passing through the security scanner you shouldn't have metal objects, mobile phones, keys or cameras in your pockets.

word.entryDescription: a type of fruit of some plants, e.g. pea, bean, cocoa
word.entryExample: Chocolate comes from the seeds (also known as beans) that grow inside the fruit (also known as pods), of the cacao tree.

word.entryDescription: a single fact, or idea that is part of an argument, a discussion or an essay
word.entryExample: I have been following your advice and practising writing short messages which focus on the main points.

word.entryDescription: having a point at the end
word.entryExample: She has narrow lips and a pointed chin.

word.entryDescription: to carry or hold in equilibrium; balance
word.entryExample: He poised the pencil on the edge of the desk.

word.entryDescription: something that can make a plant or animal ill or kill it
word.entryExample: Any poisons were removed from their house before the baby was born.

word.entryDescription: to create pollution that can kill plants or animals if they eat, drink or breathe it
word.entryExample: Chemicals used in farming can poison the water supply.

word.entryDescription: containing poison or producing poison
word.entryExample: Fugu, which is a very poisonous fish, has to be prepared extremely carefully for eating.

word.entryDescription: to quickly push your finger or the end of a long thin object against somebody or something; to prod
word.entryExample: I poked myself in the eye while I was putting on my glasses

word.entryDescription: close to or relating to the North or South Pole
word.entryExample: As global temperatures rise, the effects can be seen from the polar regions to the tropics.

word.entryDescription: a large white bear that lives in the far north
word.entryExample: Polar bears are white.

word.entryDescription: a member of the police
word.entryExample: Is she a police officer?

word.entryDescription: the building in which the police are based
word.entryExample: It's opposite the police station.

word.entryDescription: (plural 'policies') a plan or idea that has been officially decided upon by an organisation, or a government
word.entryExample: I think that by 2100, world leaders will have changed their policies on energy consumption.

word.entryDescription: somebody who works in politics, often somebody who has been elected
word.entryExample: The TV reporter used to review politicians.

word.entryDescription: a powder produced by plants and used in their reproduction, which is carried to other plants of the same species by insects or the wind
word.entryExample: The wind in the spring carries lots of pollen.

word.entryDescription: to make land, air, water, etc. unfit for or dangerous to living things by releasing dirty or harmful matter, such as smoke, chemicals, rubbish, etc into the environment
word.entryExample: Burning fossil fuels can pollute the air.

word.entryDescription: containing dirty or harmful matter
word.entryExample: The atmosphere is getting more and more polluted.

word.entryDescription: dirty or harmful matter, such as smoke, chemicals, rubbish, etc that has been released into the environment
word.entryExample: We must protect the coral reefs of the world from pollution.

word.entryDescription: a blanket or piece of material with a hole cut out of the middle for you to put your head through
word.entryExample: Ponchos have been popular in many countries in Latin America for at least two thousand years.

word.entryDescription: an area of water smaller than a lake
word.entryExample: We have a small pond in our garden.

word.entryDescription: a large area filled with water and used for swimming or playing in
word.entryExample: I didn't swim in the pool yesterday.

word.entryDescription: (of music) modern, popular, often with simple tunes and a strong beat
word.entryExample: I'm a fan of pop music.

word.entryDescription: to appear, sometimes unexpectedly
word.entryExample: Click here, and a dialog box will pop up.

word.entryDescription: liked by many people
word.entryExample: That band I saw was the most popular and I was really lucky to get tickets.

word.entryDescription: liked by an individual or limited group
word.entryExample: This area is popular with holidaymakers.

word.entryDescription: an increase in the number of people/animals living somewhere
word.entryExample: There's been a lot of population growth in recent years – there are 7 billion people on the earth now.

word.entryDescription: oats that are cooked with milk or water and eaten for breakfast
word.entryExample: I used to have tea and porridge for breakfast.

word.entryDescription: designed to be carried easily
word.entryExample: The thing I like most about my device is that it is portable.

word.entryDescription: somebody whose job is to carry things, especially luggage
word.entryExample: The hotel porter used to carry the guests' luggage.

word.entryDescription: a painting, photograph or drawing of a person, often just of their head and upper body
word.entryExample: Before photography, portrait painting was very common.

word.entryDescription: to dress or behave in a way that makes people notice you
word.entryExample: They saw Peter out posing in his new sports car.

word.entryDescription: a job
word.entryExample: Which position are you applying for?
